title: Englishpod 初级 英文播客 0259

segments.en: Hello, everyone, and welcome to EnglishPod.
segments.cn: 大家好，欢迎来到EnglishPod。

segments.en: My name is Marco.
segments.cn: 我叫Marco。

segments.en: My name is Catherine.
segments.cn: 我叫Catherine。

segments.en: And you've been with us for a little while.
segments.cn: 你们已经和我们在一起一段时间了。

segments.en: You've probably heard some of our interview series already.
segments.cn: 你们可能已经听过我们的一些访谈系列。

segments.en: Well, this is one of the later episodes in that series.
segments.cn: 这是该系列的后续剧集之一。

segments.en: That's right.
segments.cn: 没错。

segments.en: We're at part number nine.
segments.cn: 我们到了第九部分。

segments.en: We're reaching the end of our interview.
segments.cn: 我们的访谈快要结束了。

segments.en: And on this occasion, we're going to ask our employer a little bit of more information about the company and more importantly about the job.
segments.cn: 在这个场合，我们将向雇主询问一些关于公司和工作的重要信息。

segments.en: Well, this is a very important step.
segments.cn: 这是一个非常重要的步骤。

segments.en: Like you say, it's at the end of the interview.
segments.cn: 正如你所说，这是访谈的最后阶段。

segments.en: So we're going to find out more details about the job.
segments.cn: 所以我们将了解更多关于工作的细节。

segments.en: Let's take a listen to today's dialogue.
segments.cn: 让我们来听听今天的对话。

segments.en: We'll be back in a moment to talk more about it.
segments.cn: 我们稍后会回来讨论更多内容。

segments.en: Could you tell me a little about the organization?
segments.cn: 你能告诉我一些关于这个组织的情况吗？

segments.en: For example, how big is your office here?
segments.cn: 比如，你们的办公室有多大？

segments.en: Well, in total, we have around 150 employees based in Hong Kong with another 400 in our head office in Beijing.
segments.cn: 嗯，总的来说，我们在香港大约有150名员工，在北京的总部还有400名。

segments.en: The news desk staff in Hong Kong has around 80 staff.
segments.cn: 香港的新闻编辑部大约有80名员工。

segments.en: I see.
segments.cn: 我明白了。

segments.en: And how about the working hours?
segments.cn: 那工作时间呢？

segments.en: Well, as you know, Rebecca, in journalism, work hours are not exactly nine to five.
segments.cn: 嗯，正如你所知，Rebecca，在新闻行业，工作时间并不完全是朝九晚五。

segments.en: You could be on call at any time, but we do have to work very unsociable hours at times.
segments.cn: 你可能随时需要待命，但有时我们确实需要在非常不合时宜的时间工作。

segments.en: Well, I'm used to that, Mr. Parsons, so that's not really a shot for me.
segments.cn: 嗯，我对此已经习惯了，Parsons先生，所以这对我来说并不是个问题。

segments.en: Good, as long as you understand that.
segments.cn: 好的，只要你明白这一点就行。

segments.en: And when do you need to fill the vacancy, Mr. Parsons?
segments.cn: 那么，Parsons先生，你们什么时候需要填补这个空缺？

segments.en: Yesterday, but no.
segments.cn: 昨天，但不。

segments.en: We are hoping to start from the beginning of next month.
segments.cn: 我们希望从下个月开始。

segments.en: That sounds like deal.
segments.cn: 听起来不错。

segments.en: Alright, we're back.
segments.cn: 好的，我们回来了。

segments.en: So, it's obviously a very difficult job, and she asked some very key questions, so why don't we take a look at a couple of the words and phrases used there on language takeaway.
segments.cn: 显然，这是一个非常困难的工作，她问了一些非常关键的问题，所以我们来看看在语言学习中使用的一些词汇和短语。

segments.en: Language takeaway.
segments.cn: 语言学习。

segments.en: The first word that we have here for language takeaway is workforce.
segments.cn: 我们在这里的第一个词是“劳动力”。

segments.en: That's right, a workforce.
segments.cn: 没错，劳动力。

segments.en: The company's workforce.
segments.cn: 公司的劳动力。

segments.en: And that basically means all the employees that we have working for us.
segments.cn: 这基本上意味着我们所有为我们工作的人。

segments.en: That might not be in one office.
segments.cn: 这可能不在一个办公室里。

segments.en: Many companies have two, three, even a hundred offices, so the workforce means all the people who work for the company combined.
segments.cn: 许多公司有两个、三个，甚至一百个办公室，所以劳动力意味着为公司工作的所有人。

segments.en: That's right, so a workforce.
segments.cn: 没错，所以是劳动力。

segments.en: And, well, she asked about the workforce, and, well, it's obviously a pretty big company, 150 employees.
segments.cn: 她询问了劳动力，显然这是一个相当大的公司，有150名员工。

segments.en: But he also mentioned that the news desk staff in Hong Kong comprises around 80 people, or 80 staff.
segments.cn: 但他还提到香港的新闻编辑部大约有80人。

segments.en: So, this verb, to comprise, or in this case, it comprises, means to make up or to account for.
segments.cn: 所以，这个动词“包含”，在这种情况下是“包含”，意味着构成或占据。

segments.en: It's a very nice word to say it accounts for, it makes up, it's the total.
segments.cn: 这是一个很好的词，表示它占据了，总体上。

segments.en: It's the total, right.
segments.cn: 是总体，对。

segments.en: So, in this case, the news desk staff has 80 people.
segments.cn: 所以，在这种情况下，新闻编辑部有80人。

segments.en: That's a very easy way to say it.
segments.cn: 这是一种很简单的说法。

segments.en: But we could say it comprises 80 people.
segments.cn: 但我们可以说它包含80人。

segments.en: It sounds a bit better.
segments.cn: 听起来更好。

segments.en: That's right, very good.
segments.cn: 没错，非常好。

segments.en: So, now, obviously, she's going to be a reporter or a journalist.
segments.cn: 所以，显然，她将成为一名记者或新闻工作者。

segments.en: And he said that she should be on call at any time.
segments.cn: 他表示她应该随时待命。

segments.en: Okay, on call is a phrase that we often hear with jobs like journalism, but also medicine.
segments.cn: 好的，“待命”是我们在新闻行业和医学等工作中经常听到的短语。

segments.en: So doctors have to be on call very often.
segments.cn: 所以医生们经常需要待命。

segments.en: This means that you don't have to be in the office, but you have to be available to come into the office.
segments.cn: 这意味着你不必在办公室，但你必须随时可以进入办公室。

segments.en: So, when someone calls you and they say, we have an emergency, you have to be available.
segments.cn: 所以，当有人打电话告诉你，我们有紧急情况时，你必须能够到场。

segments.en: That's right.
segments.cn: 没错。

segments.en: And you see it in movies all the time.
segments.cn: 你在电影中经常看到这种情况。

segments.en: You know, doctors are on call and maybe they're already sleeping or maybe they're out, I don't know, playing soccer with their kids and they receive a phone call and they have to go to the hospital in that moment.
segments.cn: 你知道，医生们待命，可能他们已经在睡觉，或者可能他们在外面，我不知道，和孩子们踢足球，然后接到电话，必须立刻去医院。

segments.en: It's because they're on call.
segments.cn: 这就是因为他们在待命。

segments.en: That's because they're on call.
segments.cn: 这就是因为他们在待命。

segments.en: Very good.
segments.cn: 非常好。

segments.en: And so, obviously, this is a very difficult thing for someone.
segments.cn: 所以，显然，这对某人来说是非常困难的事情。

segments.en: And he explains that the work has very unsociable hours at times.
segments.cn: 他解释说，工作有时会在非常不合时宜的时间。

segments.en: Okay, so you can say that the hours are unsociable.
segments.cn: 好的，所以你可以说工作时间是不合时宜的。

segments.en: You can also say that a person is unsociable.
segments.cn: 你也可以说一个人是不合时宜的。

segments.en: It basically means that it's not very convenient for being a social person or for going out with friends and having many events to go to or fun things to do in your personal life.
segments.cn: 这基本上意味着不太方便社交或与朋友外出，参加许多活动或在个人生活中做有趣的事情。

segments.en: That's right.
segments.cn: 没错。

segments.en: So, if a person is unsociable, it means that maybe that person is not very outgoing or maybe he's always angry or grumpy.
segments.cn: 所以，如果一个人是不合时宜的，意味着那个人可能不太外向，或者可能他总是生气或不高兴。

segments.en: So, that person doesn't get along well with others.
segments.cn: 所以，那个人与他人相处得不好。

segments.en: Right, but in this case, it doesn't mean that it's a grumpy job.
segments.cn: 对，但在这种情况下，并不意味着这是一个令人不快的工作。

segments.en: It just means that because she might have to work at night very often or on the weekends, it's very hard to have a social life.
segments.cn: 这只是意味着她可能经常需要在晚上或周末工作，很难有社交生活。

segments.en: That's right.
segments.cn: 没错。

segments.en: Okay, so obviously this job is very difficult, but in the end, she was really happy with it and she said that sounds ideal, her starting time.
segments.cn: 好的，所以显然这份工作非常困难，但最后，她对此感到非常满意，并表示这听起来理想，她的开始时间。

segments.en: So, something that's ideal if it's perfect or great or the top.
segments.cn: 所以，理想的东西如果是完美的、伟大的或顶尖的。

segments.en: That's right.
segments.cn: 没错。

segments.en: Many people talk about the ideal job, right?
segments.cn: 许多人谈论理想的工作，对吧？

segments.en: The perfect job.
segments.cn: 完美的工作。

segments.en: So, that's the job that you have in your mind when you think of what is the best.
segments.cn: 所以，这就是你在思考什么是最好的时候心中所想的工作。

segments.en: That's right.
segments.cn: 没错。

segments.en: So, maybe my ideal job is different from your ideal job.
segments.cn: 所以，也许我的理想工作与你的理想工作不同。

segments.en: That's right.
segments.cn: 没错。

segments.en: So, you have ideal jobs or your ideal house or your dream house.
segments.cn: 所以，你有理想的工作或理想的房子或梦想的房子。

segments.en: Your ideal husband.
segments.cn: 你的理想丈夫。

segments.en: That's right.
segments.cn: 没错。

segments.en: So, ideal.
segments.cn: 所以，理想。

segments.en: Idealism.
segments.cn: 理想主义。

segments.en: So, why don't we listen to the dialogue again?
segments.cn: 那么，我们再听一遍对话吧？

segments.en: Let's review what Rebecca and Mr. Parsons talked about and we'll be back in a little bit with Fluency Builder.
segments.cn: 让我们回顾一下Rebecca和Parsons先生谈论的内容，稍后我们将带来流利度提升。

segments.en: Could you tell me a little about the organization?
segments.cn: 你能告诉我一些关于这个组织的情况吗？

segments.en: For example, how big is your office here?
segments.cn: 比如，你们的办公室有多大？

segments.en: Well, in total, we have around 150 employees based in Hong Kong with another 400 in our head office in Beijing.
segments.cn: 嗯，总的来说，我们在香港大约有150名员工，在北京的总部还有400名。

segments.en: The news desk staff in Hong Kong has around 80 staff.
segments.cn: 香港的新闻编辑部大约有80名员工。

segments.en: I see.
segments.cn: 我明白了。

segments.en: And how about the working hours?
segments.cn: 那工作时间呢？

segments.en: Well, as you know, Rebecca, in journalism, work hours are not exactly 9 to 5.
segments.cn: 嗯，正如你所知，Rebecca，在新闻行业，工作时间并不完全是9到5。

segments.en: You could be on call at any time, but we do have to work very unsociable hours at times.
segments.cn: 你可能随时需要待命，但有时我们确实需要在非常不合时宜的时间工作。

segments.en: Well, I'm used to that, Mr. Parsons, so that's not really a good start for me.
segments.cn: 嗯，我对此已经习惯了，Parsons先生，所以这对我来说并不是个好开始。

segments.en: Good, as long as you understand that.
segments.cn: 好的，只要你明白这一点就行。

segments.en: And when do you need to fill the vacancy, Mr. Parsons?
segments.cn: 那么，Parsons先生，你们什么时候需要填补这个空缺？

segments.en: Yesterday, but no.
segments.cn: 昨天，但不。

segments.en: We are hoping to start from the beginning of next month.
segments.cn: 我们希望从下个月开始。

segments.en: That sounds ideal.
segments.cn: 听起来很理想。

segments.en: All right, we're back.
segments.cn: 好的，我们回来了。

segments.en: So now we have four phrases for you prepared on Fluency Builder.
segments.cn: 现在我们为你准备了四个短语在流利度构建器上。

segments.en: Fluency Builder.
segments.cn: 流利度构建器。

segments.en: This first phrase is something that we say all the time in English, but I think a lot of learners make mistakes when they use it.
segments.cn: 第一个短语是我们在英语中经常说的，但我认为很多学习者在使用时会犯错误。

segments.en: The phrase is how about.
segments.cn: 这个短语是“怎么样”。

segments.en: That's right.
segments.cn: 没错。

segments.en: So you see that Rebecca was listening to what Mr. Parsons said, and she said, and how about the working hours?
segments.cn: 所以你看到丽贝卡在听帕森斯先生说的话，她说，“那工作时间怎么样？”

segments.en: So this is a way to say, and what are the working hours?
segments.cn: 这是一种说法，问“工作时间是什么？”

segments.en: But basically, it's a way to continue the conversation.
segments.cn: 但基本上，这是继续对话的一种方式。

segments.en: You can say this in many different ways, but it basically means, and what about, and or please tell me about.
segments.cn: 你可以用很多不同的方式说这个，但基本上意味着“那怎么样”或“请告诉我”。

segments.en: That's right.
segments.cn: 没错。

segments.en: Now remember that many English learners mistake the phrase how about, as if it were saying how are you or how is it?
segments.cn: 现在记住，许多英语学习者会把“怎么样”这个短语误解为“你好吗”或“怎么样？”

segments.en: No, you have to be following someone else in the conversation.
segments.cn: 不，你必须跟随对话中的其他人。

segments.en: So for example, I could say, you know what?
segments.cn: 例如，我可以说，你知道吗？

segments.en: I'm going to have a hamburger with bacon.
segments.cn: 我打算吃一个培根汉堡。

segments.en: How about you, Marco?
segments.cn: 你呢，马尔科？

segments.en: What are you going to eat?
segments.cn: 你打算吃什么？

segments.en: How about you buy me a cheeseburger?
segments.cn: 你能给我买个奶酪汉堡吗？

segments.en: Okay, so this is basically a way of saying, okay, well, maybe I'll have a cheeseburger or what are you going to have?
segments.cn: 好吧，这基本上是说，好吧，也许我会吃个奶酪汉堡，或者你打算吃什么？

segments.en: So now it's important to say don't ever make this question.
segments.cn: 所以现在重要的是说，永远不要这样提问。

segments.en: Don't ever ask, how about your weekend?
segments.cn: 永远不要问，“你周末怎么样？”

segments.en: No, no, no, no, no.
segments.cn: 不，不，不，不，不。

segments.en: How was your weekend?
segments.cn: 你周末过得怎么样？

segments.en: That's right.
segments.cn: 没错。

segments.en: My weekend was great.
segments.cn: 我的周末很好。

segments.en: How about yours?
segments.cn: 你呢？

segments.en: How about yours?
segments.cn: 你呢？

segments.en: That's continuing the conversation saying mine was good.
segments.cn: 这是在继续对话，说“我很好，你呢？”

segments.en: How was yours?
segments.cn: 你过得怎么样？

segments.en: Yeah.
segments.cn: 是的。

segments.en: Okay, so remember that when they were talking about the work hours, he said that the work hours are not exactly nine to five.
segments.cn: 好的，所以记住，当他们在谈论工作时间时，他说工作时间并不完全是九到五。

segments.en: Okay, so this is a kind of a set phrase we use often in English because a lot of people traditionally have worked from nine A.M.
segments.cn: 好的，这是一种我们在英语中经常使用的固定短语，因为很多人传统上是从早上九点工作到下午五点。

segments.en: to five P.M.
segments.cn: 他们在午餐时休息，然后回家。

segments.en: They have a break at lunch, then they go home.
segments.cn: 没错。

segments.en: That's right.
segments.cn: 所以这是一种描述传统工作时间或传统工作的方式。

segments.en: So this is a kind of measure for this is a way to describe traditional working hours or traditional jobs.
segments.cn: 所以你可以说，是的，我有一份非常好的九到五的工作。

segments.en: So you can say, yeah, I have a really nice nine to five job.
segments.cn: 你可以说，我真的不想做九到五的工作。

segments.en: You could say, I really don't want to work a nine to five job.
segments.cn: 没错。

segments.en: That's right.
segments.cn: 所以你不想要一份传统的工作，从九点工作到五点。

segments.en: So you don't want a traditional job where you're working from nine to five.
segments.cn: 对。

segments.en: Right.
segments.cn: 我认为大多数人工作时间比这稍长，但这只是说传统工作的方式。

segments.en: That's right.
segments.cn: 没错。

segments.en: Okay, nine to five job.
segments.cn: 好的，九到五的工作。

segments.en: Now why don't we move on to Rebecca saying that she is used to working long hours or being on call.
segments.cn: 现在我们为什么不继续谈丽贝卡说她习惯于长时间工作或待命。

segments.en: Right, so this construction, to be used to, I'm used to doing this, is a way to say that I already do this.
segments.cn: 对，所以这个结构，“习惯于”，我习惯于这样做，是说我已经这样做了。

segments.en: This is my experience or I have the habit of working unusual hours.
segments.cn: 这是我的经验，或者我有在不寻常的时间工作的习惯。

segments.en: That's right.
segments.cn: 没错。

segments.en: So maybe, for example, you live in a very noisy area in your neighborhood and somebody comes and visits you and they can't sleep because it's so noisy.
segments.cn: 例如，假设你住在一个非常吵闹的地方，某人来拜访你，他们因为太吵而无法入睡。

segments.en: You're used to it.
segments.cn: 你习惯了。

segments.en: Oh, you say, oh, I don't mind.
segments.cn: 哦，你会说，哦，我不介意。

segments.en: I'm used to the noise.
segments.cn: 我习惯了噪音。

segments.en: But your friend who's visiting is not used to it.
segments.cn: 但你来访的朋友并不习惯。

segments.en: Right.
segments.cn: 对。

segments.en: They don't have this noise at home.
segments.cn: 他们在家里没有这种噪音。

segments.en: So that's what happens and they can't sleep.
segments.cn: 所以这就是发生的事情，他们无法入睡。

segments.en: So when you are used to something, you have the habit or you're accustomed to it.
segments.cn: 所以当你习惯于某事时，你有这个习惯或你习惯于它。

segments.en: That's right.
segments.cn: 没错。

segments.en: Okay, and what about our last phrase?
segments.cn: 好的，我们最后一个短语呢？

segments.en: Our last phrase comes at the end and Rebecca is talking about the start date for this job.
segments.cn: 我们最后一个短语出现在最后，丽贝卡在谈论这份工作的开始日期。

segments.en: She wants to know, when do you need to fill the vacancy?
segments.cn: 她想知道，您需要什么时候填补这个空缺？

segments.en: Okay, to fill the vacancy.
segments.cn: 好的，填补空缺。

segments.en: Now we have this word vacancy and that means that it's available, right?
segments.cn: 现在我们有这个词“空缺”，意思是它是可用的，对吗？

segments.en: That's right.
segments.cn: 没错。

segments.en: So vacancy is an available thing.
segments.cn: 所以“空缺”是一个可用的东西。

segments.en: It could be a vacant place, like an apartment, like an apartment, or in this case, a vacancy in a company.
segments.cn: 它可以是一个空置的地方，比如一个公寓，或者在这种情况下，是公司中的一个空缺。

segments.en: That means a job that is available.
segments.cn: 这意味着一个可用的工作。

segments.en: That's right.
segments.cn: 没错。

segments.en: So she is asking when she can fill the vacancy.
segments.cn: 所以她在问她什么时候可以填补这个空缺。

segments.en: So we use the verb fill, to fill a vacancy.
segments.cn: 所以我们使用动词“填补”，填补空缺。

segments.en: And this sounds a lot better than saying, hey, when do I start working here?
segments.cn: 这听起来比说，“嘿，我什么时候开始在这里工作？”要好得多。

segments.en: Right.
segments.cn: 对。

segments.en: This is a polite way to say, you know, when is the job going to begin?
segments.cn: 这是一种礼貌的说法，问你知道，工作什么时候开始？

segments.en: When do you need to fill the vacancy by?
segments.cn: 你需要在什么时候填补这个空缺？

segments.en: I guess another way of saying it would be, when is the starting date?
segments.cn: 我想另一种说法是，开始日期是什么时候？

segments.en: Yes.
segments.cn: 是的。

segments.en: Okay, but as we say, also fill the vacancy is a very good option.
segments.cn: 好的，但正如我们所说，填补空缺也是一个很好的选择。

segments.en: But don't say, when do I start working?
segments.cn: 但不要说，“我什么时候开始工作？”

segments.en: Or when do we start?
segments.cn: 或者“我们什么时候开始？”

segments.en: Yeah, no, we can talk about that in a minute.
segments.cn: 是的，不，我们可以稍后再谈这个。

segments.en: Let's listen first to our dialogue one more time.
segments.cn: 让我们先再听一遍我们的对话。

segments.en: We'll be back shortly.
segments.cn: 我们很快就回来。

segments.en: Could you tell me a little about the organization?
segments.cn: 你能告诉我一点关于这个组织的事吗？

segments.en: For example, how big is your office here?
segments.cn: 例如，你们这里的办公室有多大？

segments.en: Well, in total, we have around 150 employees based in Hong Kong, with another 400 in our head office in Beijing.
segments.cn: 嗯，总的来说，我们在香港有大约150名员工，在北京的总部还有400名员工。

segments.en: The news desk staff in Hong Kong has around 80 staff.
segments.cn: 香港的新闻部大约有80名员工。

segments.en: I see.
segments.cn: 我明白了。

segments.en: And how about the working hours?
segments.cn: 那工作时间怎么样？

segments.en: Well, as you know, Rebecca, in journalism, work hours are not exactly nine to five.
segments.cn: 嗯，正如你所知，丽贝卡，在新闻行业，工作时间并不完全是九到五。

segments.en: You could be on call at any time, but we do have to work very unsociable hours at times.
segments.cn: 你随时可能需要待命，但有时我们确实需要在非常不合时宜的时间工作。

segments.en: Well, I'm used to that, Mr. Parsons, so that's not really a shock for me.
segments.cn: 嗯，我已经习惯了，帕森斯先生，所以这对我来说并不是一个震惊。

segments.en: Good, as long as you understand that.
segments.cn: 好的，只要你明白这一点。

segments.en: And when do you need to fill the vacancy, Mr. Parsons?
segments.cn: 帕森斯先生，您需要什么时候填补这个空缺？

segments.en: Yesterday, but no.
segments.cn: 昨天，但不。

segments.en: We are hoping to start from the beginning of next month.
segments.cn: 我们希望从下个月初开始。

segments.en: That sounds ideal.
segments.cn: 听起来很理想。

segments.en: So talking about working hours, being on call, or unsociable working hours, have you ever had a job where you've had to work maybe through the night?
segments.cn: 说到工作时间，待命或不合时宜的工作时间，你有没有过需要通宵工作的工作？

segments.en: Yes, I used to work in a movie theater when I was in college.
segments.cn: 有，我在大学时曾在电影院工作。

segments.en: I had a day job too, so it was kind of a mess.
segments.cn: 我还有一份白天的工作，所以有点乱。

segments.en: I was very unsociable, but I worked at a movie theater and I would start working at 6 P.M.
segments.cn: 我的工作时间很不合时宜，但我在电影院工作，通常是晚上6点开始工作。

segments.en: or 5 P.M., and I would work until 2 or 3 A.M.
segments.cn: 或者5点，工作到凌晨2点或3点。

segments.en: And so it was always busiest on Friday and Saturday.
segments.cn: 所以周五和周六总是最忙。

segments.en: And so I could never go out with my friends.
segments.cn: 所以我从来不能和朋友出去。

segments.en: Right, so while everyone was partying, you were at the movie theater.
segments.cn: 对，所以当大家在聚会时，你却在电影院。

segments.en: Exactly.
segments.cn: 正是如此。

segments.en: Or they would come to the movies and I would sneak in and bring them popcorn.
segments.cn: 或者他们会来电影院，我会偷偷带他们爆米花。

segments.en: So these unusual working hours, it's very interesting because usually, although it is a little bit more of a sacrifice, they usually pay a little bit better, right?
segments.cn: 所以这些不寻常的工作时间很有趣，因为通常虽然这有点牺牲，但通常薪水会稍微好一点，对吧？

segments.en: They do, and there are some advantages.
segments.cn: 是的，确实如此，还有一些好处。

segments.en: It means that you get to sleep in really late.
segments.cn: 这意味着你可以睡得很晚。

segments.en: You know, you don't have to wake up early.
segments.cn: 你知道的，你不需要早起。

segments.en: And you have the day off, like the entire day to do something.
segments.cn: 你有整天的时间去做事情。

segments.en: Exactly.
segments.cn: 正是如此。

segments.en: What about you?
segments.cn: 你呢？

segments.en: Have you ever worked unusual hours?
segments.cn: 你有没有工作过不寻常的时间？

segments.en: Yes, yes, I used to work for a newspaper and obviously people like their newspaper in the mornings.
segments.cn: 有的，我曾在一家报纸工作，显然人们喜欢早上看报纸。

segments.en: Right and early.
segments.cn: 对，早早的。

segments.en: Bright and early.
segments.cn: 亮亮的早晨。

segments.en: We're talking about 6 A.M.
segments.cn: 我们说的是早上6点。

segments.en: So obviously we would deliver the newspapers around 1 A.M., 2 A.M.
segments.cn: 所以显然我们会在凌晨1点、2点左右送报纸。

segments.en: from 1 A.M.
segments.cn: 从凌晨1点开始。

segments.en: to about 6 A.M.
segments.cn: 到大约早上6点。

segments.en: Wow.
segments.cn: 哇。

segments.en: So yeah, pretty unusual and very difficult because for example, for some people, for them it's great to see the sunrise.
segments.cn: 所以是的，确实很不寻常，而且非常困难，因为例如，对某些人来说，看到日出是很棒的。

segments.en: I've seen so many sunrises and it's not really romantic for me anymore.
segments.cn: 我已经看过很多次日出，对我来说已经不再浪漫了。

segments.en: We would call you a night owl, someone who's more awake at night.
segments.cn: 我们会称你为夜猫子，晚上更清醒的人。

segments.en: That's right, and I still am.
segments.cn: 没错，我仍然是。

segments.en: So we were really interested to know maybe if you had any unusual working hours.
segments.cn: 所以我们真的很想知道你是否有过任何不寻常的工作时间。

segments.en: Or do you work a 9 to 5?
segments.cn: 还是你工作的是朝九晚五？

segments.en: Yeah, do you have a 9 to 5 job?
segments.cn: 是的，你有朝九晚五的工作吗？

segments.en: So come to our website EnglishPod.com, let us know and we'll see everyone there.
segments.cn: 所以来我们的网站 EnglishPod.com，告诉我们，我们会在那里见到大家。

segments.en: Bye.
segments.cn: 再见。
